channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Antibiotic resistance is a growing threat — is climate change making it worse?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04077-0

Researchers are studying how extreme weather and rising temperatures can encourage the spread of drug-resistant infections.
item.dc:title: Antibiotic resistance is a growing threat — is climate change making it worse?
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Publisher Correction: Landscape-scale benefits of protected areas for tropical biodiversity
item.content:encoded:

Publisher Correction: Landscape-scale benefits of protected areas for tropical biodiversity
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Landscape-scale benefits of protected areas for tropical biodiversity

item.title: The handwriting of the greats, and solutions that make things worse: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00019-6

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: The handwriting of the greats, and solutions that make things worse: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Potent psychedelic drug banishes PTSD, small study finds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00012-z

Military veterans with cognitive and psychological problems saw drastic improvements after a dose of ibogaine.
item.dc:title: Potent psychedelic drug banishes PTSD, small study finds
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: A record-setting transplant heals a baby’s broken heart
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04018-x

Partial-heart transplant from a living donor allows an infant's heart valves to grow as he does.
item.dc:title: A record-setting transplant heals a baby’s broken heart

item.title: A bounty of rice comes at a price: soaring methane emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04020-3

The spread of rice paddies in sub-Saharan Africa helps to drive up atmospheric concentrations of a potent greenhouse gas.
item.dc:title: A bounty of rice comes at a price: soaring methane emissions

item.title: Start 2024 by asking: ‘Why do science?’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00011-0

Step back from the usual lab-meeting format, and ask yourself and your colleagues why you all do what you do, say Mirko Treccani and Laura Veschetti.
item.dc:title: Start 2024 by asking: ‘Why do science?’
item.dc:creator: Mirko Treccani
Laura Veschetti

item.title: US project seeks standard way to communicate research retractions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00014-x

Retracted papers continue to be cited because notices are unclear and hard to spot. Information scientist Jodi Schneider explains how consistent reporting would help to keep researchers in the loop.
item.dc:title: US project seeks standard way to communicate research retractions
item.dc:creator: Dalmeet Singh Chawla

item.title: Publisher Correction: Structural insights into cytokine cleavage by inflammatory caspase-4
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06942-4

Publisher Correction: Structural insights into cytokine cleavage by inflammatory caspase-4

item.dc:creator: Pascal Devant
Ying Dong
Julian Mintseris
Weiyi Ma

item.title: Science in 2024: what to expect this year
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00003-0

AI, moon missions, weaponized mosquitos and superfast supercomputers - we'll run through what to look out for in the new year
item.dc:title: Science in 2024: what to expect this year
item.dc:creator: Noah Baker
Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Negative mixing enthalpy solid solutions deliver high strength and ductility
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06894-9

A HfNbTiVAl10 alloy shows tensile ductility and ultrahigh yield strength from the addition of aluminium to a HfNbTiV alloy, resulting in a negative mixing enthalpy solid solution, which promotes strength and favours formation of hierarchical chemical fluctuations.
item.dc:title: Negative mixing enthalpy solid solutions deliver high strength and ductility

item.title: Disordered enthalpy–entropy descriptor for high-entropy ceramics discovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06786-y

DEED captures the balance between entropy gains and costs, allowing the correct classification of functional synthesizability of multicomponent ceramics, regardless of chemistry and structure, and provides an array of potential new candidates, ripe for experimental discoveries.
item.dc:title: Disordered enthalpy–entropy descriptor for high-entropy ceramics discovery

item.title: Na<sub>v</sub>1.7 as a chondrocyte regulator and therapeutic target for osteoarthritis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06888-7

The voltage-gated sodium channel Nav1.7 has a dual role in osteoarthritis—in chondrocytes, it promotes joint damage, and in dorsal root ganglia neurons, it increases pain transmission.
item.dc:title: Na<sub>v</sub>1.7 as a chondrocyte regulator and therapeutic target for osteoarthritis

item.title: Host genetic regulation of human gut microbial structural variation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06893-w

A meta-analysis of associations between human genetic variation and gut microbial structural variations shows that ABO genotype differentially affects the presence of Faecalibacterium prausnitzii strains containing GalNAc utilization pathway in the gut.
item.dc:title: Host genetic regulation of human gut microbial structural variation

item.title: A new antibiotic traps lipopolysaccharide in its intermembrane transporter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06799-7

A mechanism of lipid transport inhibition has been identified for a class of peptide antibiotics effective against resistant Acinetobacter strains, which may have applications in the inhibition of other Gram-negative pathogens.
item.dc:title: A new antibiotic traps lipopolysaccharide in its intermembrane transporter
item.dc:creator: Karanbir S. Pahil

item.title: Heat conductance of the quantum Hall bulk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06858-z

We measure efficient heat conductance through the electrically insulating quantum Hall bulk and propose a theoretical model based on the role played by the localized states.
item.dc:title: Heat conductance of the quantum Hall bulk
item.dc:creator: Ron Aharon Melcer
Avigail Gil
Arup Kumar Paul
Priya Tiwari
Vladimir Umansky
Moty Heiblum

Erez Berg

item.title: Ultrahigh-mobility semiconducting epitaxial graphene on silicon carbide
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06811-0

Semiconducting epigraphene aligned with single-crystal silicon carbide substrates has a band gap of 0.6  eV and room temperature mobilities 20 times larger than that of other two-dimensional semiconductors, making it suitable for nanoelectronics.
item.dc:title: Ultrahigh-mobility semiconducting epitaxial graphene on silicon carbide

item.title: Satellite mapping reveals extensive industrial activity at sea
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06825-8

Satellite imagery, vessel GPS data and deep-learning models are used to map industrial fishing vessel activities missing from public tracking systems and changes in offshore energy infrastructure in the world’s coastal waters during 2017–2021.
item.dc:title: Satellite mapping reveals extensive industrial activity at sea
item.dc:creator: Fernando Paolo
David Kroodsma
Jennifer Raynor
Tim Hochberg
Pete Davis
Jesse Cleary
Luca Marsaglia
Sara Orofino
Christian Thomas
Patrick Halpin

item.title: Oldest thylakoids in fossil cells directly evidence oxygenic photosynthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06896-7

We report the oldest direct evidence of thylakoid membranes in a parallel-to-contorted arrangement within the enigmatic cylindrical microfossils Navifusa majensis from the McDermott Formation, Tawallah Group, Australia (1.78–1.73 Ga).
item.dc:title: Oldest thylakoids in fossil cells directly evidence oxygenic photosynthesis
item.dc:creator: Catherine F. Demoulin
Yannick J. Lara
Alexandre Lambion
Emmanuelle J. Javaux

item.title: Structural transition and migration of incoherent twin boundary in diamond
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06908-6

We report atomic observations of six incoherent twin boundary configurations and structural transitions in diamond at room temperature, showing a dislocation-mediated mechanism different from metallic systems and shedding new light on grain boundary behaviour.
item.dc:title: Structural transition and migration of incoherent twin boundary in diamond
item.dc:creator: Ke Tong

item.title: A novel antibiotic class targeting the lipopolysaccharide transporter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06873-0

A tethered macrocyclic peptide antibiotic class described here—which shows potent antibacterial activity against carbapenem-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii—blocks the transport of bacterial lipopolysaccharide from the inner membrane to its destination on the outer membrane through inhibition of the LptB2FGC complex.
item.dc:title: A novel antibiotic class targeting the lipopolysaccharide transporter

item.title: Tailoring graphene for electronics beyond silicon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03991-7

The integration of non-silicon semiconductors into systems on chips is needed for advanced power and sensing technologies. A semiconducting graphene ‘buffer’ layer grown on silicon carbide is a step on this path.
item.dc:title: Tailoring graphene for electronics beyond silicon
item.dc:creator: Francesca Iacopi
Andrea C. Ferrari

item.title: A formula to predict the synthesizability of high-entropy materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03671-6

High-entropy ceramics can be transformative for several applications, but the development of this class of materials is limited by costly and time-consuming experimental processes. The disordered enthalpy–entropy descriptor is a mathematical formula that accelerates the computational discovery of synthesizable high-entropy ceramics, and has already guided the synthesis of nine new high-entropy carbonitrides and borides.
item.dc:title: A formula to predict the synthesizability of high-entropy materials

item.title: Animal Ark
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03966-8

Helping to save the planet, one pet at a time.
item.dc:title: Animal Ark
item.dc:creator: Greg Foyster

item.title: A new type of antibiotic targets a drug-resistant bacterium
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03988-2

Infections caused by drug-resistant strains of the bacterium Acinetobacter baumannii have been hard to treat in the clinic. A new class of antibiotics has been identified with the potential to tackle these microbes.
item.dc:title: A new type of antibiotic targets a drug-resistant bacterium
item.dc:creator: Morgan K. Gugger
Paul J. Hergenrother

item.title: Harvard president’s resignation amid plagiarism allegations leaves academics reeling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00009-8

Claudine Gay steps down in the face of intense scrutiny following controversial congressional testimony about antisemitism on campus.
item.dc:title: Harvard president’s resignation amid plagiarism allegations leaves academics reeling
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Satellite images reveal untracked human activity on the oceans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03983-7

Machine learning and satellite imagery have been used to map industrial infrastructure at sea — from fishing vessels to wind turbines. The findings provide a more comprehensive picture of maritime activity than ever before.
item.dc:title: Satellite images reveal untracked human activity on the oceans
item.dc:creator: Konstantin Klemmer
Esther Rolf

item.title: Long COVID is a double curse in low-income nations — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04088-x

Not only is the prevalence of the condition poorly understood, but it’s also often ignored by physicians and the wider public.
item.dc:title: Long COVID is a double curse in low-income nations — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Impacts for half of the world’s mining areas are undocumented
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04090-3

As the race to extract minerals and metals for clean-energy technologies accelerates, researchers must take more steps to map and study mines globally.
item.dc:title: Impacts for half of the world’s mining areas are undocumented
item.dc:creator: Victor Maus
Tim T. Werner

item.title: Small numbers of sodium channels on cartilage cells have a large effect on joint damage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03845-2

A type of sodium channel previously thought to be specific to neurons is also present in chondrocytes — cells that are crucial for joint health. Despite having low density, the sodium channels have an outsized role in the progression of osteoarthritis, and their genetic deletion or pharmacological inhibition reduced joint damage in mouse models.
item.dc:title: Small numbers of sodium channels on cartilage cells have a large effect on joint damage

item.title: A new class of antibiotics is cause for cautious celebration — but the economics must be fixed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04086-z

The threat of antimicrobial resistance means that new antibiotics need to be used sparingly. Governments must support their development with a long-term funding plan.
item.dc:title: A new class of antibiotics is cause for cautious celebration — but the economics must be fixed

item.title: Japan earthquakes: the science behind the deadly tremors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00010-1

A massive quake that triggered tsunamis, fires and multiple aftershocks was the largest on the country’s west coast in more than a century.
item.dc:title: Japan earthquakes: the science behind the deadly tremors
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

Ethics compliance should not delay biomedical advances

Nature, Published online: 02 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04165-1

Panama says no to more mining — a win for environmentalists
item.dc:title: Panama says no to more mining — a win for environmentalists

item.title: Guardian immune cells keep kidney stones at bay
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04019-w

Macrophages clear the urine of particles that could clump together to form painful masses.
item.dc:title: Guardian immune cells keep kidney stones at bay

item.title: How badly does climate change affect coral? I dive to find out
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04092-1

By putting on my scuba suit and keeping track of corals in French Polynesia, I hope to determine how much stress they’re under.
item.dc:title: How badly does climate change affect coral? I dive to find out
item.dc:creator: Patricia Maia Noronha

item.title: Eliminate undeclared as well as declared chemical weapons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04163-3

Eliminate undeclared as well as declared chemical weapons
item.dc:title: Eliminate undeclared as well as declared chemical weapons
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ruggiero

item.title: The research aiming to keep people healthier for longer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04089-w

An exploration of the biological reasons that people age celebrates the role of worms and flies in enabling scientific discovery — and investigates how to age well.
item.dc:title: The research aiming to keep people healthier for longer
item.dc:creator: Linda Partridge

item.title: How sharing your science in an opinion piece can boost your career
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04091-2

Don’t rely solely on academic papers to raise your professional profile. General readers are interested in your opinions, too.
item.dc:title: How sharing your science in an opinion piece can boost your career
item.dc:creator: Jane Palmer

item.title: The AI–quantum computing mash-up: will it revolutionize science?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 January 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04007-0

Scientists are exploring the potential of quantum machine learning. But whether there are useful applications for the fusion of artificial intelligence and quantum computing is unclear.
item.dc:title: The AI–quantum computing mash-up: will it revolutionize science?
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Audio long read: A new kind of solar cell is coming — is it the future of green energy?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03882-x

Perovskite–silicon ‘tandem’ photovoltaic panels could lead to cheaper electricity production.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: A new kind of solar cell is coming — is it the future of green energy?
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: The Nature Podcast highlights of 2023
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04046-7

The team select some of their favourite stories from the past 12 months.
item.dc:title: The Nature Podcast highlights of 2023
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe
Noah Baker
Dan Fox
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Super-propulsion: how sharpshooting insects flick their pee
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04167-z

High-speed cameras reveal tiny insects employing a physical phenomenon, never-before seen in a natural system to avoid drowning in their own urine
item.dc:title: Super-propulsion: how sharpshooting insects flick their pee
item.dc:creator: Noah Baker

item.title: From the archive: waltzing mice, and Louis Pasteur’s beer battle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 27 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04078-z

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: waltzing mice, and Louis Pasteur’s beer battle

item.title: Festive parody songs from the Nature Podcast
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04170-4

The Nature Podcast team have rewritten two popular holiday songs in honour of some of the biggest science stories of in 2023.
item.dc:title: Festive parody songs from the Nature Podcast
item.dc:creator: Noah Baker

item.title: How AI works is often a mystery — that's a problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04154-4

The inner workings of many AIs are mysterious, but with increasing use of such technologies in high stakes scenarios, how should their inscrutable nature be dealt with?
item.dc:title: How AI works is often a mystery — that's a problem
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Reindeer can activate sleep mode while eating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04034-x

Putting the brain into sleep mode helps to maximize food intake during bountiful Arctic summers.
item.dc:title: Reindeer can activate sleep mode while eating

item.title: How an AI-powered lion became a teaching tool
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04152-6

The mascot for King’s College London helped Andrés Gvirtz to teach a class, with a little help from generative artificial intelligence.
item.dc:title: How an AI-powered lion became a teaching tool
item.dc:creator: Andrés Gvirtz

item.title: How a surge in organized crime threatens the Amazon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04087-y

The global community needs to break the web of transnational crime networks and corruption threatening one of the world’s largest carbon sinks.
item.dc:title: How a surge in organized crime threatens the Amazon
item.dc:creator: Bram Ebus

item.title: Will superintelligent AI sneak up on us? New study offers reassurance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04094-z

Improvements in the performance of large language models such as ChatGPT are more predictable than they seem.
item.dc:title: Will superintelligent AI sneak up on us? New study offers reassurance
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: Neutrino secrets could be revealed by Earth’s atmosphere
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04085-0

Scientists typically look at the skies or take to the laboratory to probe the neutrino’s properties. But neutrinos produced in Earth’s atmosphere could reveal this long-sought information — and the experiments are already well under way.
item.dc:title: Neutrino secrets could be revealed by Earth’s atmosphere
item.dc:creator: Josh Spitz

item.title: Citations show gender bias — and the reasons are surprising
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03474-9

Gender bias in paper citations is less common among younger scientists, but it still plays a part in making women’s research less visible.
item.dc:title: Citations show gender bias — and the reasons are surprising
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: Saleemul Huq (1952–2023), climate visionary
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 22 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04166-0

A relentless climate scientist who was the voice of the voiceless in the global climate fight.
item.dc:title: Saleemul Huq (1952–2023), climate visionary
item.dc:creator: Achala C. Abeysinghe

item.title: A tale of Silk Road violence as told by a lake’s mud
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04017-y

Soot and other remnants of fires record ancient warfare along the storied trade route.
item.dc:title: A tale of Silk Road violence as told by a lake’s mud

item.title: What were some of the biggest stories of 2023? Join us for the Nature Podcast quiz!
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04161-5

In a game of twenty questions our contestants stretch their memories to remember some of the science stories that made headlines this year.
item.dc:title: What were some of the biggest stories of 2023? Join us for the Nature Podcast quiz!
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Polar bear fur-inspired sweater is thinner than a down jacket — and just as warm
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04145-5

The synthetic fibre is an aerogel coated with polyurethane and is flexible, washable and wearable.
item.dc:title: Polar bear fur-inspired sweater is thinner than a down jacket — and just as warm
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Contact-tracing app predicts risk of SARS-CoV-2 transmission
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04063-6

The risk of catching COVID-19 as calculated by a smartphone app scales with the probability of subsequently testing positive for the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, showing that digital contact tracing is a useful tool for fighting future pandemics.
item.dc:title: Contact-tracing app predicts risk of SARS-CoV-2 transmission
item.dc:creator: Justus Benzler

item.title: Politics and the environment collide in Brazil: Lula’s first year back in office
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04042-x

Brazil’s left-wing President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva grapples with deforestation, fossil-fuel pledges and commitments to Indigenous communities — all while having to work with a conservative Congress.
item.dc:title: Politics and the environment collide in Brazil: Lula’s first year back in office
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: AI consciousness: scientists say we urgently need answers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04047-6

Researchers call for more funding to study the boundary between conscious and unconscious systems.
item.dc:title: AI consciousness: scientists say we urgently need answers
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Welcome to your post-apocalyptic bunker rental!
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03891-w

A home away from home.
item.dc:title: Welcome to your post-apocalyptic bunker rental!
item.dc:creator: Wendy Nikel

item.title: How research managers are using AI to get ahead
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04160-6

For those at the interface of funding organizations and the scientific community, platforms such as ChatGPT can tackle menial tasks and free up time for relationship-building work such as coaching and mentoring.
item.dc:title: How research managers are using AI to get ahead
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Daily briefing: Criticism hits nematode cancer tests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04168-y

Doctors have raised concerns that a commercial cancer test produces high levels of false negatives and false positives. Plus, a surge in extreme forest fires fuels global emissions and what quantum theory implies about determinism.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Criticism hits nematode cancer tests
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: How I became the ‘hoodie girl’: attending conferences as a neurodiverse scientist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04157-1

Biostatistician Penny Robinson explains why conferences and networking events present challenges for neurodiverse scientists and suggests some simple fixes.
item.dc:title: How I became the ‘hoodie girl’: attending conferences as a neurodiverse scientist
item.dc:creator: Anna Napolitano

item.title: Why 2023 was a bittersweet year for Brazilian science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04041-y

Expectations were high after Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva won the presidency. But some scientists are frustrated at the slow pace of change.
item.dc:title: Why 2023 was a bittersweet year for Brazilian science
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: This GPT-powered robot chemist designs reactions and makes drugs — on its own
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 December 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-04073-4

A system called Coscientist scours the Internet for instructions, then designs and executes experiments to synthesize molecules.
